body: so we are making each component "Contractable" in java interface speak, meaning you have the option to fix the time. Ultimately, we have two ways of fulfilling a contract: the classifier estimates how long it will take itself and (adaptively) configures itself appropriately (relevant to RISE and interval length esp), but then a higher level controller is able to impose an algorithmic constraint (e.g.  stop with fewer trees if the contract is fulfilled).

so I imagine the final hive-cote will
1) look for precomputed results, if present use them
2) if not put each component in its own thread,
3) allow the component to either estimate accuracy in its own way (e.g. bagging) or wrap in a cross validator
4) determine the contract to give each component
so then you can just build HiveCote with a fixed time and it will do the best it can. The research issue is then, how to balance all these factors intelligently. We use a simplified reinforcement learning approach at the moment, but plenty to do
Is HIVE-COTE implementation ready for use yet?
hi, I believe it is on the hive-cote branch, @jasonlines will know
Thanks for this great repo! Has HIVE-COTE already been implemented/merged to master branch?
All good, I saw the implementation [here](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/db86ed7a0c63599e26deb86d0bc03422e1bb8f8e/sktime/classification/hybrid/_hivecote_v1.py) üëç

@MatthewMiddlehurst, @TonyBagnall, I think we need to design and write up a proper contract time interface - perhaps in the form of a mixin that specifies interfaces. There also should be generic unit tests for contractable estimators.

rename.to: design and API specification: contract time

body: do you want to make a start for this, @MatthewMiddlehurst?

Currently working on getting HC2 in the package (#842), as I have told a number of people we would try to get a working version this summer.

Happy to take a look after, however.
yes we need HC2 equivalence first, but a simple interface for contractable classifiers makes sense.

we now have hc2 equivalence. We discussed this at classifier dev meeting on 20/10/21. We are not sure it merits an interface/mixin. 
"We need a proper specification for contractable algorithms, i.e., what attributes and/or methods should they implement."

The Contractable interface would be a placeholder, since the contract is set as a single variable (time in minutes) in the constructor and there are no methods associated with it. It might contain a couple of variables and nothing else. 

Now benefit would be for testing instance of in unit testing, but I don't think this capability should be unit tested, at least not in the standard unit testing. We are trying to get each test under 20 secs. Contracting is meant for long runs, at least an hour, and is not meant to be exact. I am not sure how to usefully unit test it.  TTo do it sensibly will add 10+ minutes to the test time for little benefit. Happy to hearr your thoughts @fkiraly , but I think we should close this issue.

rename.from: design and API specification: contract time
rename.to: [ENH] design and API specification: contract time

body:
I thought I had decided no, but now I'm not decided on whether to have this interfac/mixin. It would have two variables and an accessor, since we have to set through constructor

class Contractable:
     impose_time_contract = False
     contract_time_in_millis = 0

it does ensure standard variable names
